title: 108_hr2061
content: The Act is titled the "National Youth Anti-Drug Media Campaign Reauthorization Act of 2003" and includes general improvements to the national anti-drug media campaign. The Drug-Free Media Campaign Act of 1998 is amended to the National Youth Anti-Drug Media Campaign Act, focusing on preventing drug abuse among young people in the United States, increasing awareness of the impact of drug abuse, and encouraging parental involvement. The Director, in consultation with the Partnership for a Drug Free America, determines the purposes and strategy of the national media campaign to prevent drug abuse among young people. The Director is responsible for implementing a focused national media campaign and approving the strategy. The Director can use funds for advertisements targeting minority, ethnic, or special audiences if the Partnership for a Drug-Free America cannot provide them, with prior notice to specific committees required. In subsection (b), the number is changed from 105 to 106, and a matching requirement is introduced for no-cost match of equivalent value of advertising broadcast time and print space or in-kind contributions to the national media campaign. The Director ensures that all no-cost matches for advertising material must relate to substance abuse prevention. Advertising material donated at no cost to the national media campaign is exempt from sponsorship identification requirements. Additionally, the Director must ensure responsible use of federal funds, with a minimum of 85% allocated each fiscal year. For each fiscal year, at least 85% of funds under this subtitle must be used for national media campaign advertising. A maximum of $5,000,000 can be used annually for developing advertising material. SEC. 104. FINANCIAL AND PERFORMANCE ACCOUNTABILITY. The Director is required to conduct audits and examinations of records as specified in the Federal Property and Administrative Services Act. An independent entity must evaluate the effectiveness of the national media campaign annually using data from various studies and publications. An independent entity will assess the national media campaign annually using data from various studies and publications, submitting a report to Congress as required. The Director is required to submit an annual report to Congress detailing the national media campaign's strategy, accomplishments, efficiency, advertising plans, responsible fund usage, and contracts with external entities. Authorization of $195,000,000 annually for the Office of National Drug Control Policy for fiscal years 2004 through 2008.
